ygData.subject: Re: Genetic Art using NEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Mattias, I think it s a really cool app as well, though as you say it s been done before with different evolutionary methods.  But I think interactive

Hi Mattias,

I think it's a really cool app as well, though as you say it's been 
done before with different evolutionary methods.  But I think 
interactive evolution has a lot of potential in the future.

Anyway, I'm wondering, are your networks recurrent, in which case 
the order in which you present coordinates would matter in a kind of 
strange way?  

An idea your project brought to my mind was maybe a "roving eye"-
like artist could be evolved: It could start out in the middle and 
just decide on its own which directions to draw in and how much ink 
to drop at each step.  You could feed it coordinates as well, but it 
would decide on the order it to visit them.  

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Mattias Fagerlund" <mattias@c...> 
wrote:
> > That's cool...elaborate, if you would!
> 
> Certainly;
> 
> This is not the first genetic art evolver, I think Karl Simms was 
first,
> though Richard Dawkins did some early work. It's not even my first 
genetic
> art evolver, it's like my third or something.
> 
> Anyway, I feed the neural network with the coordinates of each 
pixel and
> let the network output the shade of that pixel.
> 
> The user clicks on the picture that he likes and hits "New 
Generation". A
> new batch of images is created using the fitness specified by the 
user.
> 
> If the user clicks on may images, they may be crossed over in a 
few of the
> next generation images.
> 
> This program violates a few of the NEAT advantages;
>  * It doesn't use species (there'd be not point)
>  * It doesn't start minimally (that would be dull)
> 
> I've put up a version here;
> http://www.CambrianLabs.com/Mattias/DelphiNEAT/File/GeneticArt.zip
> 
> Be warned, it's very rough and you can't save nor load images. So 
if you
> evolve the best image ever, man, it's gone!
> 
> cheers,
> mattias
